text: Ebrington Barracks
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I do not know where I may be when this preface is read. As I write it
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in August 1916, I am at Ebrington Barracks, Londonderry, recovering
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: from a slight wound. But it does not greatly matter where I am; my
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreams are here before you amongst the following pages; and writing in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a day when life is cheap, dreams seem to me all the dearer, the only
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: things that survive.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Just now the civilization of Europe seems almost to have ceased, and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nothing seems to grow in her torn fields but death, yet this is only
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for a while and dreams will come back again and bloom as of old, all
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the more radiantly for this terrible ploughing, as the flowers will
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bloom again where the trenches are and the primroses shelter in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shell-holes for many seasons, when weeping Liberty has come home to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Flanders.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: To some of you in America this may seem an unnecessary and wasteful
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: quarrel, as other people's quarrels often are; but it comes to this
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that though we are all killed there will be songs again, but if we
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were to submit and so survive there could be neither songs nor dreams,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nor any joyous free things any more.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And do not regret the lives that are wasted amongst us, or the work
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that the dead would have done, for war is no accident that man's care
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: could have averted, but is as natural, though not as regular, as the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: tides; as well regret the things that the tide has washed away, which
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: destroys and cleanses and crumbles, and spares the minutest shells.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And now I will write nothing further about our war, but offer you
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: these books of dreams from Europe as one throws things of value, if
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: only to oneself, at the last moment out of a burning house.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: DUNSANY.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: A Tale of London
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Come," said the Sultan to his hasheesh-eater in the very furthest
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lands that know Bagdad, "dream to me now of London."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the hasheesh-eater made a low obeisance and seated himself
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: cross-legged upon a purple cushion broidered with golden poppies, on
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the floor, beside an ivory bowl where the hasheesh was, and having
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: eaten liberally of the hasheesh blinked seven times and spoke thus:
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "O Friend of God, know then that London is the desiderate town even of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all Earth's cities. Its houses are of ebony and cedar which they roof
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with thin copper plates that the hand of Time turns green. They have
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: golden balconies in which amethysts are where they sit and watch the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sunset. Musicians in the gloaming steal softly along the ways; unheard
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their feet fall on the white sea-sand with which those ways are
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strewn, and in the darkness suddenly they play on dulcimers and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: instruments with strings. Then are there murmurs in the balconies
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: praising their skill, then are there bracelets cast down to them for
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: reward and golden necklaces and even pearls.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Indeed but the city is fair; there is by the sandy ways a paving all
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alabaster, and the lanterns along it are of chrysoprase, all night
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: long they shine green, but of amethyst are the lanterns of the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: balconies.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "As the musicians go along the ways dancers gather about them and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dance upon the alabaster pavings, for joy and not for hire. Sometimes
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a window opens far up in an ebony palace and a wreath is cast down to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a dancer or orchids showered upon them.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Indeed of many cities have I dreamt but of none fairer, through many
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marble metropolitan gates hasheesh has led me, but London is its
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: secret, the last gate of all; the ivory bowl has nothing more to show.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And indeed even now the imps that crawl behind me and that will not
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: let me be are plucking me by the elbow and bidding my spirit return,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for well they know that I have seen too much. 'No, not London,' they
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: say; and therefore I will speak of some other city, a city of some
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: less mysterious land, and anger not the imps with forbidden things. I
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: will speak of Persepolis or famous Thebes."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: A shade of annoyance crossed the Sultan's face, a look of thunder that
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: you had scarcely seen, but in those lands they watched his visage
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: well, and though his spirit was wandering far away and his eyes were
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: bleared with hasheesh yet that storyteller there and then perceived
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the look that was death, and sent his spirit back at once to London as
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: a man runs into his house when the thunder comes.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And therefore," he continued, "in the desiderate city, in London, all
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their camels are pure white. Remarkable is the swiftness of their
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: horses, that draw their chariots that are of ivory along those sandy
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ways and that are of surpassing lightness, they have little bells of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: silver upon their horses' heads. O Friend of God, if you perceived
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their merchants! The glory of their dresses in the noonday! They are
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: no less gorgeous than those butterflies that float about their
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets. They have overcloaks of green and vestments of azure, huge
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: purple flowers blaze on their overcloaks, the work of cunning needles,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the centres of the flowers are of gold and the petals of purple. All
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: their hats are black--" ("No, no," said the Sultan)--"but irises are
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: set about the brims, and green plumes float above the crowns of them.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "They have a river that is named the Thames, on it their ships go up
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with violet sails bringing incense for the braziers that perfume the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets, new songs exchanged for gold with alien tribes, raw silver
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for the statues of their heroes, gold to make balconies where the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: women sit, great sapphires to reward their poets with, the secrets of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: old cities and strange lands, the earning of the dwellers in far
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: isles, emeralds, diamonds, and the hoards of the sea. And whenever a
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ship comes into port and furls its violet sails and the news spreads
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: through London that she has come, then all the merchants go down to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the river to barter, and all day long the chariots whirl through the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: streets, and the sound of their going is a mighty roar all day until
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening, their roar is even like--"
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Not so," said the Sultan.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Truth is not hidden from the Friend of God," replied the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hasheesh-eater, "I have erred being drunken with the hasheesh, for in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the desiderate city, even in London, so thick upon the ways is the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: white sea-sand with which the city glimmers that no sound comes from
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the path of the charioteers, but they go softly like a light
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sea-wind." ("It is well," said the Sultan.) "They go softly down to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the port where the vessels are, and the merchandise in from the sea,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: amongst the wonders that the sailors show, on land by the high ships,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and softly they go though swiftly at evening back to their homes.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "O would that the Munificent, the Illustrious, the Friend of God, had
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: even seen these things, had seen the jewellers with their empty
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: baskets, bargaining there by the ships, when the barrels of emeralds
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: came up from the hold. Or would that he had seen the fountains there
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: in silver basins in the midst of the ways. I have seen small spires
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: upon their ebony houses and the spires were all of gold, birds
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: strutted there upon the copper roofs from golden spire to spire that
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have no equal for splendour in all the woods of the world. And over
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: London the desiderate city the sky is so deep a blue that by this
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: alone the traveller may know where he has come, and may end his
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fortunate journey. Nor yet for any colour of the sky is there too
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great heat in London, for along its ways a wind blows always from the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: South gently and cools the city.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Such, O Friend of God, is indeed the city of London, lying very far
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: off on the yonder side of Bagdad, without a peer for beauty or
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: excellence of its ways among the towns of the earth or cities of song;
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and even so, as I have told, its fortunate citizens dwell, with their
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hearts ever devising beautiful things and from the beauty of their own
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fair work that is more abundant around them every year, receiving new
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: inspirations to work things more beautiful yet."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And is their government good?" the Sultan said.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "It is most good," said the hasheesh-eater, and fell backwards upon
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the floor.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: He lay thus and was silent. And when the Sultan perceived he would
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: speak no more that night he smiled and lightly applauded.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And there was envy in that palace, in lands beyond Bagdad, of all that
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dwell in London.

text: In front of a spacious fireplace of the old kind, when the logs were
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: well alight, and men with pipes and glasses were gathered before it in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great easeful chairs, and the wild weather outside and the comfort
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that was within, and the season of the year--for it was Christmas--and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hour of the night, all called for the weird or uncanny, then out
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: spoke the ex-master of foxhounds and told this tale.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I once had an odd experience too. It was when I had the Bromley and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sydenham, the year I gave them up--as a matter of fact it was the last
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: day of the season. It was no use going on because there were no foxes
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: left in the county, and London was sweeping down on us. You could see
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it from the kennels all along the skyline like a terrible army in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: grey, and masses of villas every year came skirmishing down our
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valleys. Our coverts were mostly on the hills, and as the town came
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down upon the valleys the foxes used to leave them and go right away
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out of the county and they never returned. I think they went by night
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and moved great distances. Well it was early April and we had drawn
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: blank all day, and at the last draw of all, the very last of the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: season, we found a fox. He left the covert with his back to London and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: its railways and villas and wire and slipped away towards the chalk
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: country and open Kent. I felt as I once felt as a child on one
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: summer's day when I found a door in a garden where I played left
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: luckily ajar, and I pushed it open and the wide lands were before me
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and waving fields of corn.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: We settled down into a steady gallop and the fields began to drift by
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: under us, and a great wind arose full of fresh breath. We left the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: clay lands where the bracken grows and came to a valley at the edge of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the chalk. As we went down into it we saw the fox go up the other side
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: like a shadow that crosses the evening, and glide into a wood that
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: stood on the top. We saw a flash of primroses in the wood and we were
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: out the other side, hounds hunting perfectly and the fox still going
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: absolutely straight. It began to dawn on me then that we were in for a
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: great hunt, I took a deep breath when I thought of it; the taste of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the air of that perfect Spring afternoon as it came to one galloping,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and the thought of a great run, were together like some old rare wine.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Our faces now were to another valley, large fields led down to it,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with easy hedges, at the bottom of it a bright blue stream went
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: singing and a rambling village smoked, the sunlight on the opposite
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slopes danced like a fairy; and all along the top old woods were
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: frowning, but they dreamed of Spring. The "field" had fallen of and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were far behind and my only human companion was James, my old first
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: whip, who had a hound's instinct, and a personal animosity against a
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: fox that even embittered his speech.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Across the valley the fox went as straight as a railway line, and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again we went without a check straight through the woods at the top. I
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: remember hearing men sing or shout as they walked home from work, and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sometimes children whistled; the sounds came up from the village to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the woods at the top of the valley. After that we saw no more
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: villages, but valley after valley arose and fell before us as though
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: us the fox went dead up-wind like the fabulous Flying Dutchman. There
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was no one in sight now but my first whip and me, we had both of us
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: got on to our second horses as we drew the last covert.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Two or three times we checked in those great lonely valleys beyond the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: village, but I began to have inspirations, I felt a strange certainty
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: within me that this fox was going on straight up-wind till he died or
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: until night came and we could hunt no longer, so I reversed ordinary
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: methods and only cast straight ahead and always we picked up the scent
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: again at once. I believe that this fox was the last one left in the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: villa-haunted lands and that he was prepared to leave them for remote
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: uplands far from men, that if we had come the following day he would
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not have been there, and that we just happened to hit off his journey.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: on, like the lazy but unresting shadows of clouds upon a summer's day,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: towards a hidden farm, one of them singing softly; no other sounds,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but ours, disturbed the leisure and the loneliness of haunts that
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: (even as China, they say, in some of her further mountains does not
title: Tales of Wonder

text: And now the day and our horses were wearing out, but that resolute fox
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: held on. I began to work out the run and to wonder where we were. The
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: last landmark I had ever seen before must have been over five miles
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: back and from there to the start was at least ten miles more. If only
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: we could kill! Then the sun set. I wondered what chance we had of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: killing our fox. I looked at James' face as he rode beside me. He did
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: not seem to have lost any confidence yet his horse was as tired as
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: would outlast all possible endurance both of the fox and the horses,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: if the scent held good and he did not go to ground, otherwise night

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The Secret of the Sea
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: In an ill-lit ancient tavern that I know, are many tales of the sea;
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but not without the wine of Gorgondy, that I had of a private bargain
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening for the greater part of a year.

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there never came the tale for which I sought, and as a last resort I
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

text: I had long known that there is in ships a will or way of their own,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and had even suspected that when sailors die or abandon their ships at
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sea, a derelict, being left to her own devices, may seek her own ends;
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: but I had never dreamed by night, or fancied during the day, that the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ships had a god that they worshipped, or that they secretly slipped
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away to a temple in the sea.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Over the fourth glass of the wine that the gnomes so sinfully brew but
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: have kept so wisely from man, until the bargain that I had with their
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: elders all through that autumn night, the sailor told me the story. I
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it; nor is it from delicacy that I refrain from writing these oaths
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: verbatim, but merely because the horror they caused in me at the time
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: troubles me still whenever I put them on paper, and I continue to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shudder until I have blotted them out. Therefore, I tell the story in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

text: rum and blood and the sea.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: You would take a ship to be a dead thing like a table, as dead as bits
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of iron and canvas and wood. That is because you always live on shore,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and have never seen the sea, and drink milk. Milk is a more accursed
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: drink than water.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: What with the captain and what with the man at the wheel, and what
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: with the crew, a ship has no fair chance of showing a will of her own.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: There is only one moment in the history of ships, that carry crews on
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: board, when they act by their own free will. This moment comes when
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: all the crew are drunk. As the last man falls drunk on to the deck,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the ship is free of man, and immediately slips away. She slips away at
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: once on a new course and is never one yard out in a hundred miles.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It was like this one night with the Sea-Fancy. Bill Smiles was there
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: before for fear that anyone should call him a liar. Nobody dislikes
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: being hung as much as Bill Smiles would, but he won't be called a
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: liar. I tell the tale as I heard it, relevancies and irrelevancies,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: though in my more decent words; and as I made no doubts of the truth
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of it then, I hardly like to now; others can please themselves.

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: It is not often that the whole of a crew is drunk. The crew of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the Sea-Fancy was no drunkener than others. It happened like this.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: were plotting against him, or a sudden bleeding he had from both his
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ears, made him think that drinking might be bad for his health. Next
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

text: The Watch-tower
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I sat one April in Provence on a small hill above an ancient town
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that Goth and Vandal as yet have forborne to "bring up to date."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: On the hill was an old worn castle with a watch-tower, and a well with
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: narrow steps and water in it still.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: The watch-tower, staring South with neglected windows, faced a broad
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: valley full of the pleasant twilight and the hum of evening things: it
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saw the fires of wanderers blink from the hills, beyond them the long
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: forest black with pines, one star appearing, and darkness settling
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: slowly down on Var.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sitting there listening to the green frogs croaking, hearing far
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: voices clearly but all transmuted by evening, watching the windows in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the little town glimmering one by one, and seeing the gloaming dwindle
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: solemnly into night, a great many things fell from mind that seem
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: important by day, and evening in their place planted strange fancies.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Little winds had arisen and were whispering to and fro, it grew cold,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and I was about to descend the hill, when I heard a voice behind me
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saying, "Beware, beware."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So much the voice appeared a part of the evening that I did not turn
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: round at first; it was like voices that one hears in sleep and thinks
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to be of one's dream. And the word was monotonously repeated, in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: French.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When I turned round I saw an old man with a horn. He had a white beard
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: marvellously long, and still went on saying slowly, "Beware, beware."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: He had clearly just come from the tower by which he stood, though I
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had heard no footfall. Had a man come stealthily upon me at such an
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hour and in so lonesome a place I had certainly felt surprised; but I
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: saw almost at once that he was a spirit, and he seemed with his
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: uncouth horn and his long white beard and that noiseless step of his
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to be so native to that time and place that I spoke to him as one does
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to some fellow-traveller who asks you if you mind having the window
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: up.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I asked him what there was to beware of.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Of what should a town beware," he said, "but the Saracens?"
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Saracens?" I said.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Yes, Saracens, Saracens," he answered and brandished his horn.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "And who are you?" I said.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I, I am the spirit of the tower," he said.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When I asked him how he came by so human an aspect and was so unlike
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the material tower beside him he told me that the lives of all the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: watchers who had ever held the horn in the tower there had gone to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: make the spirit of the tower. "It takes a hundred lives," he said.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "None hold the horn of late and men neglect the tower. When the walls
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: are in ill repair the Saracens come: it was ever so."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "The Saracens don't come nowadays," I said.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: But he was gazing past me watching, and did not seem to heed me.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "They will run down those hills," he said, pointing away to the South,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "out of the woods about nightfall, and I shall blow my horn. The
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: people will all come up from the town to the tower again; but the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: loopholes are in very ill repair."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "We never hear of the Saracens now," I said.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "Hear of the Saracens!" the old spirit said. "Hear of the Saracens!
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: They slip one evening out of that forest, in the long white robes that
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they wear, and I blow my horn. That is the first that anyone ever
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hears of the Saracens."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "I mean," I said, "that they never come at all. They cannot come and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: men fear other things." For I thought the old spirit might rest if he
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knew that the Saracens can never come again. But he said, "There is
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nothing in the world to fear but the Saracens. Nothing else matters.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: How can men fear other things?"
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Then I explained, so that he might have rest, and told him how all
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Europe, and in particular France, had terrible engines of war, both on
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: land and sea; and how the Saracens had not these terrible engines
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: either on sea or land, and so could by no means cross the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Mediterranean or escape destruction on shore even though they should
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: come there. I alluded to the European railways that could move armies
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: night and day faster than horses could gallop. And when as well as I
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: could I had explained all, he answered, "In time all these things pass
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: away and then there will still be the Saracens."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And then I said, "There has not been a Saracen either in France
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: or Spain for over four hundred years."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And he said, "The Saracens! You do not know their cunning. That was
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: ever the way of the Saracens. They do not come for a while, no not
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they, for a long while, and then one day they come."
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And peering southwards, but not seeing clearly because of the rising
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: mist, he silently moved to his tower and up its broken steps.

text: How Plash-Goo Came to the Land of None's Desire
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: In a thatched cottage of enormous size, so vast that we might consider
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it a palace, but only a cottage in the style of its building, its
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: timbers and the nature of its interior, there lived Plash-Goo.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Plash-Goo was of the children of the giants, whose sire was Uph. And
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the lineage of Uph had dwindled in bulk for the last five hundred
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: years, till the giants were now no more than fifteen foot high; but
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Uph ate elephants which he caught with his hands.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Now on the tops of the mountains above the house of Plash-Goo, for
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Plash-Goo lived in the plains, there dwelt the dwarf whose name was
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Lrippity-Kang. And the dwarf used to walk at evening on the edge of
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the tops of the mountains, and would walk up and down along it, and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: was squat and ugly and hairy, and was plainly seen of Plash-Goo.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And for many weeks the giant had suffered the sight of him, but at
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: length grew irked at the sight (as men are by little things), and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: could not sleep of a night and lost his taste for pigs. And at last
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: there came the day, as anyone might have known, when Plash-Goo
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: shouldered his club and went up to look for the dwarf.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And the dwarf though briefly squat was broader than may be dreamed,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: beyond all breadth of man, and stronger than men may know; strength in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: its very essence dwelt in that little frame, as a spark in the heart
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of a flint: but to Plash-Goo he was no more than mis-shapen, bearded
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and squat, a thing that dared to defy all natural laws by being more
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: broad than long.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: When Plash-Goo came to the mountain he cast his chimahalk down (for so
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he named the club of his heart's desire) lest the dwarf should defy
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: him with nimbleness; and stepped towards Lrippity-Kang with gripping
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hands, who stopped in his mountainous walk without a word, and swung
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: round his hideous breadth to confront Plash-Goo. Already then
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Plash-Goo in the deeps of his mind had seen himself seize the dwarf in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: one large hand and hurl him with his beard and his hated breadth sheer
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: down the precipice that dropped away from that very place to the land
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: of None's Desire. Yet it was otherwise that Fate would have it. For
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the dwarf parried with his little arms the grip of those monstrous
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hands, and gradually working along the enormous limbs came at length
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: to the giant's body where by dwarfish cunning he obtained a grip; and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: turning Plash-Goo about, as a spider does some great fly, till his
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: little grip was suitable to his purpose, he suddenly lifted the giant
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: over his head. Slowly at first, by the edge of that precipice whose
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: base sheer distance hid, he swung his giant victim round his head, but
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: soon faster and faster; and at last when Plash-Goo was streaming round
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the hated breadth of the dwarf and the no less hated beard was
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: flapping in the wind, Lrippity-Kang let go. Plash-Goo shot over the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: edge and for some way further, out towards Space, like a stone; then
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he began to fall. It was long before he believed and truly knew that
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: this was really he that fell from this mountain, for we do not
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: associate such dooms with ourselves; but when he had fallen for some
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: while through the evening and saw below him, where there had been
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: nothing to see, or began to see, the glimmer of tiny fields, then his
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: optimism departed; till later on when the fields were greener and
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: larger he saw that this was indeed (and growing now terribly nearer)
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: that very land to which he had destined the dwarf.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: At last he saw it unmistakable, close, with its grim houses and its
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: dreadful ways, and its green fields shining in the light of the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: evening. His cloak was streaming from him in whistling shreds.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: So Plash-Goo came to the Land of None's Desire.

text: The Three Sailors' Gambit
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Sitting some years ago in the ancient tavern at Over, one afternoon in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Spring, I was waiting, as was my custom, for something strange to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: happen. In this I was not always disappointed for the very curious
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: leaded panes of that tavern, facing the sea, let a light into the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: low-ceilinged room so mysterious, particularly at evening, that it
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: somehow seemed to affect the events within. Be that as it may, I have
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: seen strange things in that tavern and heard stranger things told.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: And as I sat there three sailors entered the tavern, just back, as
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: they said, from sea, and come with sunburned skins from a very long
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: voyage to the South; and one of them had a board and chessmen under
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: his arm, and they were complaining that they could find no one who
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: knew how to play chess. This was the year that the Tournament was in
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: England. And a little dark man at a table in a corner of the room,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: drinking sugar and water, asked them why they wished to play chess;
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and they said they would play any man for a pound. They opened their
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: box of chessmen then, a cheap and nasty set, and the man refused to
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: play with such uncouth pieces, and the sailors suggested that perhaps
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: he could find better ones; and in the end he went round to his
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: lodgings near by and brought his own, and then they sat down to play
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: for a pound a side. It was a consultation game on the part of the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sailors, they said that all three must play.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Well, the little dark man turned out to be Stavlokratz.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Of course he was fabulously poor, and the sovereign meant more to him
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: than it did to the sailors, but he didn't seem keen to play, it was
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: the sailors that insisted; he had made the badness of the sailors'
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: chessmen an excuse for not playing at all, but the sailors had
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: overruled that, and then he told them straight out who he was, and the
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: sailors had never heard of Stavlokratz.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: Well, no more was said after that. Stavlokratz said no more, either
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: because he did not wish to boast or because he was huffed that they
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: did not know who he was. And I saw no reason to enlighten the sailors
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: about him; if he took their pound they had brought it upon themselves,
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and my boundless admiration for his genius made me feel that he
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: deserved whatever might come his way. He had not asked to play, they
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: had named the stakes, he had warned them, and gave them the first
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: move; there was nothing unfair about Stavlokratz.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: I had never seen Stavlokratz before, but I had played over nearly
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: every one of his games in the World Championship for the last three or
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: four years; he was always of course the model chosen by students. Only
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: hand.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and mutter together before every move, but they muttered so low that

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: That was his name.

title: Tales of Wonder

text: be tried for murder at the High Court of Bow.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

text: ability who had gone into the Cabinet in order to enhance his forensic
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

text: it always hangs their clients they hardly like to neglect it.

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: and women had wept when they heard that. They did not weep when they
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: heard Watkyn-Jones. Some tittered. It no longer seemed a right and
title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

text: of laughter too. And what was the joke? For in so grave a place as a
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: prisoner pulled from his pocket the three slips of paper: and

text: perceived for the first time that the one on which the first and best
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: joke had been written had become quite blank. Yet he could remember
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: it, and only too clearly. And he told it from memory to the Court.
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: "An Irishman once on being asked by his master to buy a morning paper
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: said in his usual witty way, 'Arrah and begorrah and I will be after
title: Tales of Wonder
author: Dunsany, Lord

text: wishing you the top of the morning.'"

author: Dunsany, Lord

text: No joke sounds quite so good the second time it is told, it seems to
title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

text: the awful stillness with which this one was received; nobody smiled;
title: Tales of Wonder

text: and it had killed twenty-two men. The joke was bad, devilish bad;
title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

title: Tales of Wonder

text: then he has wandered, avoiding ports and roaming lonely places. Two
title: Tales of Wonder

author: Dunsany, Lord

title: Tales of Wonder
